messages: 2da76487dd675c9c57c9c8a791f69791 (12:10): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: one more question: is there a tag which lets me define a data range, i.e. row/col 2/2 to 6/6 of a table so that I can use this range within the output tag?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:10): no
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:12): http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3C!DOCTYPE%20html%3E%0A%3Cp%3E%3Cinput%20placeholder%3D'text%0Atext%0Atext'%3E%0A
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:12): interesting in WebKit
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:13): hah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:33): so... <input type=file multiple> would result in different actual fields in the field data set per file
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:34): but with <input type=email multiple>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:34): what do we do with input.value?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:40): maybe we should introduce input.values
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:41): i'd make it comma-separated but that would suck because addr-spec can contain commas
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:47): maybe make .value contain the value if multiple="" is absent, and be empty otherwise
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:48): and have .values be null except for this case, and in this case have it return some sort of mutable DOMStringList
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:48): not that i really want to have to invent a whole new API just for this
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:49): i could just disallow the quoted-string part of addr too
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:51): aw man and domain-literal has crazy ass syntax too
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:51): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: what's your expected fallback behavior?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:51): who the hell invented this
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:51): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: using .value would have nice fallback behavior
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:52): but if i do that i really have to redefine addr-spec to be radically simpler
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:52): notes that Mail.app allows the user to type a comma after an email address
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:52): wonders how that works if the addresses can contain commas
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:53): Gmail splits addresses on commas too
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:53): they can only contain commas in quoted bits
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:53): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: can the addresses be whitespace-separated?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:53): good XML and SGML vocabularies separate tokens with whitespace
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:54): "foo,bar"@[\,].com   appears to be a valid e-mail address
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:54): as does   " "@[\ ]
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:54): that's crazy
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:54): Does email delivery with addresses like that work?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:54): i doubt it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:55): i'm just gonna redefine addr-spec to be what users expect
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:55): dot-atom "@" dot-atom
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:55): expects more controversy with HTML5 redefining things from the IETF realm
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:56): Why does anything have to be redefined, rather than just defining new terms?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:57): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: you mean defining a new term like "Web email address"?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:57): well i didn't redefine addr-spec
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:58): i just defined "Valid email address"
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:58): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: are you coordinating this with mailto URIs?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:59): mailto: is defined in rfc2368 and allows the whole gamut of batshit crazy stuff like comments and quoted strings and backslash-escaped characters and everything.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:59): we're already (as of wf2) narrower than that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:59): i'm just making it even narrower.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:00): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I mean defining a new term like "sensible-addr-spec", rather than redefining addr-spec, since it sounded like that was possible what people were talking about
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:04): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, how will a <input type=email name=name multiple> element be submitted? Will it be like this: ?name=<email/>&name=<email/>
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:04): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: that would be backwards-incompatible
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:05): so it would need to be ?name=<some delimted list of emails>
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:17): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, AUDITNAV is a bad name to use. If PING isn't acceptable, now about something like NOTIFY?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:18): As a bonus, people couldn't fake it with XHR
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:19): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: tell julian, not me
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:19): i'll use whatever he gets approved

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:21): agrees that PING is a bad name, because it's got pretty much nothing to do with what everyone else in the computer networking world means by 'ping' (i.e. a reachability/RTT-measurement tool)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:24): isn't motivated enough to start another naming debate on the list.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:24): i agree that for the http name PING is suboptimal
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:25): i don't care if it's AUDITNAV or something else
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:25): NOTIFY seems a bit vague for what we're defining, but it could be defined more vaguely too
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:25): AUDIT would be better
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:25): i just don't really care
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:25): i have enough troubles with html, http can take care of itself :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:27): http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Document_Type_Declaration&diff=253488659&oldid=prev
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:27): typical wikipedia

d95d8ca8960fe7974e3f649e9fa6fafa (13:30): Anyone know if there will be a JS interface to form data handling in the upcoming specs? Specifically I'm thinking of something like: var fData = someForm.toPostData(); window.location = '/path?' + fData;
d95d8ca8960fe7974e3f649e9fa6fafa (13:31): Because currently there's no native way of doing it and any naive implementation will vary from browser to browser AFAICT.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:37): can't you just set the form's action to "/" and post the form normally?
d95d8ca8960fe7974e3f649e9fa6fafa (13:39): Sure, but if you've got existing data (be it form based or otherwise) there's no programmatic way to get a multipart/form-data representation.
d95d8ca8960fe7974e3f649e9fa6fafa (13:40): I'm not sure if this is relevant to #whatwg's goals but I figure I can be pointed in the appropriate direction if not :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:40): why would you want that representation?
d95d8ca8960fe7974e3f649e9fa6fafa (13:41): For AJAX mainly.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:41): it's definitely something that would be in our goals if you can convince us there's a good reason for it :-)
d95d8ca8960fe7974e3f649e9fa6fafa (13:41): Ooh, interesting :)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:42): it's interesting how wikipedia is incorrectly using the abbreviation "DTD" to mean Document Type Declaration
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:43): hmm, well, perhaps their not. It's just ambiguous since their using headings like "HTML 4.01 DTDs"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:44): nn

d95d8ca8960fe7974e3f649e9fa6fafa (13:44): So, for example, if you wanted to do an XHR with the POST method using multipart/form-data there's no standard way of stitching the data together such that it is indistinguishable from the browser's equivalent.
d95d8ca8960fe7974e3f649e9fa6fafa (13:45): Perhaps I should put a mailing list message together ...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:57): does wikipedia have something like cvs blame?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:59): finds this piece of encyclopedic writing: "There is currently no indication as to whether HTML 5 will support RDFa, or be limited just to microformats."
